items.title: Donald Trump Rescinds Biden-Era Executive Order on AI Safety
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- Donald Trump rescinded a Biden-era executive order on generative AI safety on his first day in office.
- The original Biden order required developers like OpenAI to share safety test results with the government and develop safety standards.
- Trump signed 78 executive orders, including the rescission of the order related to AI safety, as he prioritizes AI development in his administration.
keywords: National Institute of Standards and Technology

items.title: Instagram is reportedly trying to attract TikTok creators with large bonuses
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Instagram is offering creators cash bonuses between $10,000 to $50,000 per month to post Reels exclusively on their platform.
- This initiative aims to attract TikTok creators during TikTok's absence from app stores.
- The bonuses require creators to publish their videos on Instagram before other platforms like TikTok.
- Instagram had launched a Reels bonus program in 2021, but it was later cut in 2023 due to reduced payouts.
- TikTok is facing a chaotic situation in the US due to recent compliance laws, impacting its availability.
- Instagram has made various updates recently to cater to TikTok creators, including new profile formats and extended Reels length to three minutes.
- Some TikTok creators express dissatisfaction with Meta's recent policy changes, which may affect their willingness to switch platforms.

items.title: A24’s Opus blurs the line between fandom and faith in first trailer
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary:
- The trailer for A24's *Opus* explores the spiritual experience of meeting music stars.
- Directed by Mark Anthony Green, the film follows journalist Ariel Ecton (Ayo Edebiri) as she investigates eccentric superstar Alfred Moretti (John Malkovich).
- Moretti emerges after three decades to share music exclusively with select celebrities and invites Ariel to his home.
- The trailer hints at cult-like activities surrounding Moretti, showcasing frantic guests and Ariel's terrified reactions.
- *Opus* is set to be released in theaters on March 14, 2025, and is anticipated as a disturbing thriller.

items.title: How the future of sports streaming died
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- Venu Sports aimed to consolidate sports viewing into one platform but faced criticisms regarding cost and competitiveness.
- Despite initial excitement, the service encountered significant challenges leading to its shutdown.
- The Vergecast episode features insights from Jacob Feldman about the origins and demise of Venu, and discusses the implications for the future of sports streaming.

items.title: What to expect at Samsung’s Galaxy S25 event
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Samsung's Galaxy Unpacked event is scheduled for January 22nd at 1PM ET.
- The event will be streamed on YouTube, Samsung's website, and newsroom page.
- Expected announcements include Galaxy S25, S25 Plus, and S25 Ultra with design tweaks.
- The S25 Ultra may feature slightly rounder corners based on leaked renders.
- Galaxy S25 devices will support Qi2 wireless charging, possibly needing a magnetic case for full experience.
- Phones will run One UI 7 based on Android 15, featuring new camera app and HDR content disabling option.
- No Galaxy S25 Slim is expected to launch in the US.
- Potential discussions about the “Project Moohan” VR headset during the event.

items.title: Samsung needs to give us a reason to care about new phones every year
items.author: Allison Johnson
items.summary:
- The Galaxy S25 series is rumored to be uninspiring and similar to previous models.
- Samsung's launch events no longer feel special; they often repeat previous innovations.
- Hardware innovation is stagnating; software features are becoming the focus.
- Apple's recent launches, like the iPhone 16, also highlight minimal hardware changes.
- Potentially exciting developments include slimmer designs for future models.

items.title: Marvel Snap is back in the US
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Marvel Snap resumes operation in the US after being offline due to a TikTok ban law affecting its ByteDance-owned publisher.
- Developer Second Dinner plans to bring more services in-house and partner with a new publisher to prevent future disruptions.
- The game is not yet available on Apple’s App Store or Google Play, but is still live on Steam.
- TikTok service was restored after a brief period, although it remains missing from app stores.
- An executive order by President Trump delays enforcement of the law banning ByteDance apps for 75 days.

items.title: Trump signs executive order to reverse Biden’s electric vehicle policies
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- President Trump signed an executive order to eliminate Biden’s electric vehicle policies, which he called a “mandate”.
- He intends to weaken tailpipe emission standards, impacting environmental protections.
- The orders aim to halt funding for EV charging through the Inflation Reduction Act and pause other financial disbursements related to EV initiatives.
- Trump plans to review regulations that may burden domestic energy development, particularly impacting emissions standards.
- There is no existing EV mandate, but Trump targets regulations incentivizing EV sales to slashing greenhouse gas emissions.
- The auto industry has invested heavily in EV development, with EV sales increasing by 7.3% in 2024.
- Trump is also looking to ramp up mining for non-fuel minerals, potentially linked to interests in Greenland’s resources.
- Transportation contributes about 28% of US greenhouse gas emissions, which are linked to climate change.

items.title: Trump Signs Order to Delay TikTok Ban for 75 Days
items.author: Adi Robertson
items.summary:
- President Trump issued an executive order directing the DOJ not to enforce TikTok’s required divestment from ByteDance for 75 days.
- The order aims to provide time for determining the appropriate course regarding TikTok and prevents penalties against American companies involved with it.
- Trump’s executive order follows a bipartisan law effective January 19, 2025, which could impose heavy penalties for noncompliance.
- Legal ambiguity exists regarding the legality of pausing the ban as no sale to a non-foreign adversary has been announced.
- Major companies may still avoid reinstating TikTok due to significant potential legal penalties, despite Trump’s assurances.

items.title: Donald Trump pulls US out of Paris climate agreement
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- Donald Trump signed an executive order to exit the [Paris climate agreement](https://unfccc.int/process-and-meetings/the-paris-agreement) for the second time during his presidency.
- The Paris accord, adopted in 2015, aimed to limit global temperature rise and was joined by nearly 200 countries.
- The US will now be among the only countries, including Iran, Libya, and Yemen, not participating in the agreement.
- The withdrawal is expected to take one year from notification to the UN to be finalized.
- Environmental advocates criticize the move as a defiance of scientific consensus regarding climate change.

items.title: Brendan Carr is officially in charge of the FCC
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- Brendan Carr officially appointed as chair of the FCC, with plans to set agency agenda and implement regulations affecting tech and media industries.
- Priorities include jobs and growth through spectrum, infrastructure, and the space economy, referencing his involvement in Project 2025.
- Proposed actions involve limiting Section 230 immunity for tech companies, supporting rural broadband funding, and expediting satellite launch approvals.
- Carr addresses national security concerns related to TikTok, amidst conflicting views from Trump on the app's risks.
- He may revoke spectrum licenses based on hosting decisions, a contentious issue highlighted during Kamala Harris's appearance on SNL.
- Approval of measures requires a third Republican vote; Trump has nominated Mark Meador for a seat on the commission.

items.title: Vivek Ramaswamy steps down from DOGE
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Vivek Ramaswamy steps down from co-leading DOGE (Department of Government Efficiency).
- He plans to run for Ohio governor, necessitating his departure from DOGE.
- Ramaswamy's exit follows internal friction and dissatisfaction with his participation alongside Elon Musk.

items.title: Dynasty Warriors: Origins is a refreshing take on the legendary series
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Developed by Koei-Tecmo’s Omega Force, this is the tenth game in the Dynasty Warriors series.
- The game adapts the Chinese historical novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms and introduces a single protagonist known as the Wanderer.
- Combat includes light and heavy attacks, skills unlocked through use, and mechanics that require strategic play to defeat powerful enemy generals.
- Battles take place on large maps with objectives such as defeating enemy leaders and saving allied generals, enhancing the feeling of heroism.
- Released on PlayStation, Xbox, and PC.

items.title: Fujifilm’s new stabilized binoculars deliver even more zoom
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Fujifilm launched two models in the Techno-Stabi line: TS-L2040 (20x zoom) and TS-L1640 (16x zoom).
- Both models will be available starting January 31, 2025, priced at $1,299.95 and $1,199.95, respectively.
- New binoculars are smaller and lighter than previous models, with improved waterproofing and stabilization features.
- They use AAA batteries, offering up to 30 hours of stabilization and an auto power-off feature after 60 minutes.
- Both models have 40mm objective lenses to improve light intake and brightness.

items.title: Trump declared a ‘national energy emergency’
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- Donald Trump declares a 'national energy emergency' to accelerate fossil fuel infrastructure development.
- This move marks the beginning of his administration's push to boost oil and gas production and reverse climate initiatives from the Biden era.
- Trump promises to refill the US strategic reserves and export energy globally, while aiming to discard the 'Green New Deal' and electric vehicle mandates.
- The Inflation Reduction Act signed by Biden provides $369 billion for climate action, which Trump has pledged to rescind any unspent funds.
- Concerns arise about potential increases in costs for electric vehicles due to Trump's plans to eliminate subsidies introduced by the Biden administration.

items.title: X, Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube sign EU pledge to tackle hate speech
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Meta, Google, TikTok, and X pledged to prevent and remove illegal hate speech on their platforms as part of the European Commission's revised voluntary commitments under the Digital Services Act.
- Signatories including Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, and others committed to transparency in hate speech detection, third-party monitoring, and reviewing at least two-thirds of hate speech reports within 24 hours.
- EU Commissioner Michael McGrath emphasized the threat of hate and polarization to EU values and noted that companies face no penalties for backing out of these voluntary commitments.

items.title: Donald Trump is officially president again
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- Donald Trump has been sworn in as the 47th president of the US on January 20, 2025.
- His second term is expected to impact the tech industry significantly, with influences in tariffs, immigration, and regulation.
- Major tech companies have begun to adapt their strategies in light of Trump's return, including changes in company policies and engagement with Trump.
- Key areas of focus include tariffs on China, US surveillance for deportations, climate change efforts, environmental regulation, AI chip export controls, potential antitrust cases, and immigration policy for tech workers.
- Trump plans to sign numerous executive orders on his first afternoon, potentially affecting trade and the TikTok situation.

items.title: Canon’s new app lets you live stream from multiple cameras, just not Canon’s
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Canon has announced a new live streaming app called Live Switcher Mobile for iPhones and iPads.
- The app allows connecting and switching between video feeds from up to three mobile devices.
- Current limitations include 720p video quality, watermarked output, and ads in the interface.
- A paid subscription ($17.99/month) removes ads and watermarks and increases quality to 1080p.
- The app does not currently support Canon's own digital cameras but will in the future.
- It allows streaming to YouTube, Facebook, and other RTMP-compatible platforms, but comment display is limited to YouTube and Facebook.
- Users can switch feeds manually or set automatic intervals for switching.

items.title: A first look at Nvidia’s flagship RTX 5090 compared to the RTX 4090
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Nvidia’s GeForce RTX 5090 Founders Edition graphics card is set to launch later this month.
- The RTX 5090 features a new packaging design with a smaller inner box.
- The card requires a new power adapter and can use existing 12VHPWR cables.
- The RTX 5090 is slimmer than the RTX 4090, designed as a two-slot card instead of three.
- Cooling has been redesigned with double flow-through fans and a revised PCB layout for better airflow.
- The card includes three DisplayPort 2.1b ports and one HDMI 2.1b port, but the ports are flipped.
- The design introduces refined LED lighting and a new darker metal housing color.
- A full review comparing the RTX 5090's performance to the RTX 4090 will follow soon.

items.title: Welcome to the era of gangster tech regulation
items.author: Elizabeth Lopatto
items.summary:
- President Donald Trump takes office amid allegations of widespread corruption and donor influence.
- Major tech figures like Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos are reportedly attending the inauguration, with significant financial contributions to Trump's campaign.
- The crypto industry seeks lenient regulations and favors from the government, such as designating cryptocurrency a national priority.
- The tech industry faces numerous lawsuits, and Trump's administration may selectively enforce antitrust laws.
- Tech executives aim to secure government contracts, especially in defense, with a focus on military investments.
- Potential conflicts between tech giants could arise due to competing interests in government contracts and regulatory outcomes.
- Overall, the situation posits a troubling dynamic where corporate interests increasingly influence government policy, thereby worsening conditions for the average citizen.

items.title: All the rumors about the iPhone Air
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Apple may launch a new model called iPhone 17 Air this fall.
- The iPhone Air is designed to be ultra-thin, potentially around 5.5mm to 6mm thick.
- It will feature a possibly 48-megapixel rear camera and a 24-megapixel front camera.
- The battery will be challenging due to the slim design, with rumors suggesting a battery size of 3,000 to 4,000mAh.
- The display is rumored to use LTPO OLED technology for better refresh rates and power efficiency, with a size of about 6.6 inches.
- Apple plans to use in-house chips for Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and cellular modem.
- Pricing is uncertain, with speculations ranging from below $999 to above $1,299.
- The design aims to enhance sales after previous models underperformed.

items.title: Bluesky and X launch new video feeds amid TikTok uncertainties
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- TikTok faces uncertainty while Bluesky and X enhance video features.
- New video feeds and tabs allow users to discover vertical videos easily.
- Bluesky introduces customizable video feeds targeting specific hashtags like #BookSky.
- X launches a 'Video Tab' for personalized video content across various topics.
- Users may need to refresh the Bluesky app to see the new features.

items.title: Oppo’s next foldable is about as thin as USB-C allows
items.author: Dominic Preston
items.summary:
- Oppo's upcoming Find N5 foldable is as thin as its USB-C port when unfolded.
- Expected rebranding as OnePlus Open 2 for the US market.
- Product manager Zhou Yibao shared images on Weibo highlighting its thickness, claiming it's the thinnest foldable yet, estimated at around 4mm.
- The Find N5's thickness is compared to two Chinese yuan coins and a stack of four ID cards.
- IPX9-rated for water resistance; tested against high-temperature, high-pressure jets.
- Previous model, Find N3, was rebranded as OnePlus Open in the West, and similar marketing is anticipated for the Find N5.

items.title: Trump touts his plan to save TikTok during his victory rally
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- At a victory rally, Trump proposed a plan to create a joint venture with the US to save TikTok from being banned.
- The plan suggests the US government would own 50% of TikTok, raising First Amendment issues regarding content moderation.
- Trump credited TikTok for helping him win over young voters and emphasized the need to keep jobs in the US instead of giving business to China.

items.title: TikTok is back, but where are Marvel Snap, CapCut, and Lemon8?
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- TikTok has partially returned in the US after a nationwide ban, while Marvel Snap, CapCut, and Lemon8 remain blocked.
- Users attempting to access these apps see messages indicating they are banned.
- The ban on these apps follows a federal divest-or-ban law that took effect on January 19th, 2025.
- Both Google Play Store and Apple App Store prevent downloads for these apps due to legal restrictions.
- Uncertainty remains regarding when these apps will be available again.

items.title: TikTok’s service providers still risk billions in penalties for bringing it back online
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- President-elect Trump cannot extend TikTok's ban deadline without risking penalties for service providers.
- TikTok is banned until sold to a non-Chinese company; potential fines could reach $850 billion for providers like Apple and Google.
- Trump's assurances to companies may not protect them from legal repercussions; Supreme Court enforcement could occur up to five years later.

items.title: Instagram announces a blatant CapCut clone
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Instagram has launched a new video editing app called Edits, which aims to compete with CapCut.
- The app will be available for preorder on the iOS App Store and launches on March 13, 2025.
- Edits will provide tools like a live insights dashboard, green screens, and collaboration features for creators.

items.title: TikTok isn’t back in the App Store yet
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- TikTok announced on Sunday that it’s in the process of restoring service but remains unavailable on the App Store and Google Play.
- Users searching TikTok on the App Store see a message indicating the app isn't available in their region, while Google Play states downloads are paused due to US legal requirements.
- TikTok has returned for some users in the US, attributing restoration to President Trump’s efforts, with no further comments from involved companies.

items.title: TikTok is coming back online in the US
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- TikTok has announced it is "in the process of restoring service" in the US after a brief shutdown.
- The service interruption lasted about half a day, aligning with a federal ban on the app.
- Company thanks President Trump for providing clarity to service providers, allowing TikTok to operate for over 170 million Americans and support over 7 million small businesses.
- Users can access TikTok via mobile and desktop web but the app is not available on iOS and Android app stores, which show messages regarding its unavailability.
- The original shutdown was due to the impending federal ban, though there's been a shift in enforcement strategy under the Biden administration.

items.title: The TikTok shutdown is locking out non-US users, too
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- TikTok's US shutdown affects non-US users, with complaints of access issues from users in other countries.
- Some users on Reddit identified that using a VPN routing through the US caused access problems, while others claimed issues despite not using a VPN.
- Users from various countries including Canada, Germany, Australia, Greece, and Poland report being locked out, raising questions about TikTok's response to account creation locations and region settings.

items.title: Trump says he’ll delay TikTok ban, but the platform must be sold
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- President-elect Donald Trump proposes a joint venture for TikTok, aiming for the US to own 50% of the app.
- Trump intends to issue an executive order to delay the TikTok ban to protect national security.
- Republican lawmakers express skepticism about halting the TikTok ban without a legitimate sale to eliminate foreign ownership.

items.title: Trump’s second inauguration: live updates and how to watch
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Donald Trump will be sworn in as the 47th president of the United States on January 20th.
- Tech leaders including Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Tim Cook are expected to attend.
- A livestream of the inauguration will be provided by C-SPAN starting at 7AM ET with the ceremony at 12PM ET.
- The event will occur indoors at the United States Capitol Rotunda due to cold weather projections.
- Senators Warren and Bennet are pressing tech firms about their donations to Trump’s inauguration fund, expressing concerns about motives behind the contributions.

items.title: New year, new Switch, new Severance
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- New Nintendo Switch 2 announced with a teaser video, expected to be a unique successor to the original.
- Season 2 of *Severance* highly anticipated, with the first season receiving critical acclaim.
- Nokia Design Archive launched, showcasing the history and innovations in Nokia's design.
- New game *Donkey Kong Country Returns HD* available for the current Switch.
- Raycast Focus app released, enhancing productivity by blocking distractions.

items.title: The tech to build the holodeck
items.author: Janko Roettgers
items.summary:
- Gaussian splatting is a new 3D capture method revolutionizing tech industry applications.
- Developed in 2023, it uses fuzzy, translucent blobs to create detailed, photorealistic 3D objects.
- Companies like Niantic, Google, and Meta are integrating Gaussian splatting into their products, enhancing AR and VR experiences.
- Niantic aims to democratize 3D capture with their Scaniverse app, facilitating the creation of a 3D map of the world.
- Meta's Hyperscape demo showcases photorealistic environments for exploratory experiences in VR.
- The technology allows for more creative flexibility in 3D video capture, even in low-light conditions.
- Future advancements may combine Gaussian splatting with generative AI to simplify and enhance the capture process.

items.title: Apple says it’s following the law by removing TikTok from the App Store
items.author: Richard Lawler
items.summary:
- Apple has removed TikTok and other ByteDance apps from the App Store in the US as of January 19, 2025, following legal requirements.
- The removal is part of the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act.
- Apps already installed by users will not be removed, but redownloading or updating them will be impossible in the US.
- Affected apps include TikTok, CapCut, and Marvel Snap among others.
- TikTok's legal appeal to the Supreme Court was unsuccessful, allowing the law to take effect.

items.title: Marvel Snap is banned, just like TikTok
items.author: Richard Lawler
items.summary:
- Marvel Snap, linked to ByteDance, has been banned alongside TikTok due to new U.S. laws.
- Players lost access to the game on January 19, 2025, with announcements of an ongoing effort to restore it.
- Second Dinner, the game's developer, expressed surprise over the ban and ensured players that they are working to resolve the issue.
- The app has disappeared from iOS and Android platforms, while some PC players report issues logging in.
- Other apps from ByteDance also faced similar bans, expanding the impact beyond just Marvel Snap.

items.title: TikTok ban: all the news on the app’s shutdown in the US
TikTok is down in the US
items.author: Richard Lawler
items.summary:
- TikTok has ceased operations in the US due to a ban-or-divest law effective January 19.  
- The app is removed from app stores and users are unable to access it, impacting 170 million users.  
- TikTok announced this shutdown amid ongoing legal disputes and negotiations with the Trump administration for potential reinstatement.

items.title: How to bulk download and save your TikTok videos
items.author: Barbara Krasnoff
items.summary:
- TikTok may be banned in the US as of January 19th, prompting creators to save their videos.
- TikTok allows individual downloads but not bulk downloads via their platform.
- Methods for bulk downloads include using Repurpose.io, browser DevTools console, or a Chrome extension like myfaveTT.
- Repurpose.io offers a free trial for the first 10 videos, and costs $35 monthly after that.
- Users can bulk download by utilizing the DevTools console to gather video links and then using services like TOKdownload.
- Always good to back up online videos due to security concerns or potential bans.

items.title: TikTok starts warning US users it will be “temporarily unavailable”
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
- TikTok will go offline in the US starting January 19th due to a federal ban.
- The app has begun notifying users about the temporary unavailability of its services.
- TikTok is seeking to restore services quickly, contingent on actions from the incoming Trump administration.
- An internal memo expresses disappointment and indicates ongoing efforts to reinstate TikTok.
- The company has been aware of the ban since April but lacked a backup plan for enforcement.
- The Biden administration has transferred enforcement responsibilities to the Trump administration, which may delay the ban's implementation by 90 days.
- TikTok users are voicing their frustrations, urging politicians to lift the ban.

items.title: Genshin Impact’s developer to pay $20 million fine to settle FTC charges
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Cognosphere agrees to a $20 million settlement with the FTC due to misleading loot box practices.
- The company marketed loot boxes to children and misled users about winning odds and real costs of transactions.
- Under the settlement, Cognosphere is required to delete data of children under 13 without parental consent and must disclose pricing and odds more transparently.

items.title: Microsoft opens testing for Windows AI search
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Microsoft is testing AI-powered Windows search in a new dev channel build for Windows 11 Insider testers.
- The feature uses semantic indexing, allowing searches for local files using casual language, and does not require an internet connection.
- Currently supports image and text file formats such as JPEG, PNG, PDF, TXT, and XLS, limited to indexed locations.
- Will roll out gradually to Snapdragon-powered Copilot+ PCs, with support for Intel and AMD models later.
- The search feature will expand to include cloud data stored in OneDrive in the future.

items.title: Biden White House says TikTok’s threat to go dark is a ‘stunt’
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre labeled TikTok's threat to "go dark" as a stunt ahead of Trump's inauguration.
- Jean-Pierre stated there is no need for TikTok to take drastic actions before the new administration takes over.
- TikTok demands stronger assurances from the Biden administration regarding liability for US service providers amid a Supreme Court ruling supporting the ban.
- TikTok CEO Shou Chew expressed gratitude for Trump's support and noted a potential 90-day extension to avoid the ban, which Trump suggested during an interview.

items.title: EV startup Canoo has filed for bankruptcy
items.author: Wes Davis
items.summary:
- Canoo has filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy in Delaware, ceasing operations immediately.
- The company estimates assets worth $126 million and owes over $164 million to creditors.
- A Bankruptcy Trustee will oversee the liquidation process.
- Canoo failed to secure support from the US Department of Energy and foreign investors.
- The company previously idled its Oklahoma operations and lost all of its founders.
- Canoo had agreements to produce shuttles for NASA and build electric delivery vans for Walmart.
